titleStmt.title: Illustrissimis viris tam pietate quam prudentiâ atque auctoritate spectatissimis; ornatissimis D. Johanni Leveretto. D Josiæ Winslowæo. D. Guilielmo Leitto. Cottonus Matherus. Grindallus Rawsonus. Urianus Oakes. D.D.D Q.
Theses. 1678.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

Gubernatoribu • Honoratiſſimis Coeteriſque in M • giſtratus Onere et Honore Conjugatis, ad Reipublicae clavum jugiter excubantibus, incolumitatis publicae apprimé ſtudioſis; Nec non Reverendiſſimis cum Academ • ae, tum Eccleſiatum Curatoribus, Theologis Doctiſſimis et Graviſſimis; Omnibus detuó et ſingulis bonarum Literarum candidans, benevolis Academiae 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉

Theſes haſce, quas ( 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 ) Sub Rev: URIANO OAKES, Eccleſiae Cantabrigienſis Paſtore, Collegii Harvardini Praeſide pro tempore, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 diſcutiendas, proponunt juvenes 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉

list.item: ARs est ordinata Intelligentia, Scientiae, Sapientiae, & Prudentiae colligat • o & concurſus.
2. Ars praecipuè conſistit in Theoriâ Regulae, & Praxi ſecundum Regulam.
3. Ʋtrumque perf • citur per Analyſin & Geneſin.
4. Libri Scripturae & Creaturae ſunt mineralia ex quibus haec Regula eſt effodienda.
5. Author entium est Author Art • um.
6. Praecepta Artis id agunt, ut veteri querelae, Ars longa, vita brevis, medeantur.

7.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 eſt objectum & finis artis.
8. Praxis est Theoriae finis, medium finis ultimi.
9. Ʋſu confunduntur, ſpeculatione ſeparantur pra • tomena.
10. G • neſis & Analyſis eadem veſtigia premunt.

11. In compoſitione mundi Geneſis fuit, in ejusdem
que reſolutione Analyſis erit maximè conſpicua.
12. Ars ut naturam juvet, non ut impediat adhibetur.
13. Non ab artifice Ars, ſed ab arte artifex creatur.
14. Aliquis in omnibus, nullus in ſingulis, non eſt 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 vtrum
☞ Non datur Metaphyſica ab aliis Diſciplinis distincta.
16. In artium orbe adhuc restat multa Terra incognita.
DIalectica est Ars rationis.
2 Logicae munus totum est diſcernere & diſponere.
3. Affectio est forma Argumenti.
4. Cauſa cognoſcitur per effectum tanquam per aliquid notius nois, effectus vero per cauſam, tanquam per aliquid notius naturâ.
5. Fortuna (quae dicitur, eſt particula divinae providentiae.
6. Materia eſt omnium entium a primo communis.
7. Forma eſt principium diſtinctionis.
8. Poſita forma, ponuntur eſſe, diſtinctio, & operatio.
9. Finis rei nihil aliud eſt quam rei bonitas, movens • fficieniem, • rficiens eff • ctum.
10. Finium intentione eſt finis conceptus, finis in executione eſt finis natus.
11. Exiſtintia eſt Eſſentia actualis.
12. Locus & Tempus ſunt entia merè Logica
13 Dive • ſis & Oppoſitis aequè convenit diſſentire, ſed non convenit aeq • è • iſſentire.
14. Sola oppoſita realiter diſtinguuntur.
15. Comparatio id agit, ut comparata aeque nota evadant.
16 Diſtributio maximè accurata eſt dichotomia.
17. Totum in diſtributione, eſt pars in definitione.
18. Pa • s in distributione eſt totum in definitione.
19. Genus habet naturam diſtinctam á ſpeciebus, non ſeparatam.
20. Teſtimonium divinum eſt •••• niſſimum.
21. Omnis veritas est certa, licet non neceſſaria.
22 Diſc • eta Axiomata non concludunt, ſed diſtinguunt.
23. D • axiomate immediatè, de ſillogi • mo mediaté ſit judicium.
24 Nulla datur ſyllogiſmi contingentia.
25. Tertium Argumentum eſt ſyllogiſmi Arbiter.
26. Explicatus primus eſt ſyllogiſmus refutationis.
GRammatica eſt Antidotus contra confuſarum linguarum maledictionem.
2. Suum Idioma ſervare eſt omni lingua privilegium neceſſarium.
3. Prima ſermonis gratia eſt purè loqui.
4. Nota rerum aliae poſſunt cudi praeter verba et literas.
5. Aliquid de populorum moribus poteſt colligi ex ipſorum linguis.
6. D • ſtinctio inter verba Homonyma eſt praecipuus Orthographiae uſus.
7. Q • antitas & accentus ſunt ſyllabarum condimenta.
8. Syntaxis eſt cynoſura quae lectorem dirigit in ſenſum ſententiarum.
RHetoricae munus eſt dictamina Rationis Phantaſiae applicare.
2 Rhetorica facit bonum apparens.
3 Copia Troporum fluxit ex inopiâ verborum.
4 Omnis tropus in axi • matibus ſinon aptiſſime adhibitus, est Cat • chreſis
5 Hyperbole vel ſupra vel infra metam ſemper rolat.
6 Hyberbole quamvis ultra fidem, non tamen ultra modum eſſe debet.
7 Allegoria eſt metaphorarum conventus.
8 Tropus doctis, figura Idietis eſt elocutionis pars mellitiſſima.
9 Apoſtrophe eſt orationis circumactio, ut auditores commodius, inopinato opprimat.
ULtima unitas eſt numeri forma.
2 Extractio radicum est arithmeticae pars longè digniſſima.
3 Lineae Geometricae ſunt reales, quamvis non ſenſibus perceptibiles.
4 Linea non conſtat è punctus.
5 Lineae ſolidae oriuntur è corporis ſectione.
6 Aequalitas eſt menſura inaequalitatis.
7 Recto non datur rectius.
8 Ʋbi Anguli ſunt aequicruri Baſis tantummodo conſtituit differentiam.
9 Pyramis eſt ſoli • orum prima.
10 Aequator eſt praecipua tempo • is menſura.
11 Aſtronomiae pars utiliſſima non adhuc ex hypotheſibus colligenda exhibetur.
12 Aſtrologia, quae dicitur judiciaria eſt ſani judi • ii expers.
PHyſica est ars benë naturandi
